name: granulated blast furnace slag production | granulated blast furnace slag | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/20087/documentation

This dataset represents the intermediate treatment of raw blast furnace slag, producing an output of granulated blast furnace slag (GBFS). GBFS resembles a natural sand grain, with a more angular form. It has a glass content of over 95% and presents excellent hydraulic properties. The GBFS usually goes through a subsequent grinding process, generating a supplementary cementitious material called ground granulated blast furnace slag (GGBFS). In Brazil, around 70% of the blast furnace slag used in cement making is grinded jointly with clinker, after the granulation process. Therefore, this dataset focuses exclusively in the blast furnace slag granulation process, which happens in the steelmaking company. This dataset is mainly based on primary data provided by one Brazilian steelmaking plant, representing an average condition of GBFS production in Brazil. Water and electricity consumption come from internal company reports, and granulated blast furnace slag daily production is measured by scales within the plant. Particulate emission data was extrapolated by Marceau and VanGeem (2003), exclusively for their granulation process. Other emissions data listed on that publication were not considered here either because they were related to drying or grinding, or because consulted Brazilian experts claimed they didn't make sense in the local granulation process. According to the company which provided primary granulation data, there is no mass loss within the granulation process.

From the generation of blast furnace slag from pig iron production, at the steelmaking plant. 

This activity ends with the granulation of blast furnace slag. It includes the water and electricity consumed for the granulation process, and emissions that arise from it. Infrastructure, machinery and administration activities not included
category: C:Manufacturing/23:Manufacture of other non-metallic mineral products/239:Manufacture of non-metallic mineral products n.e.c./2395:Manufacture of articles of concrete, cement and plaster

processDocumentation.timeDescription: LCI based on primary company data from January to June of 2017. The start of period date was set to 2015 since the granulation process's technology as modeled has been available for some time already.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Dataset based on primary data provided by one Brazilian steelmaking company that represents average conditions
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Granulation is performed using pressurized cold water jets. Granulated slag is subsequently dried in filters within the storage silo.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: Data refers to one Brazilian steelmaking plant, extrapolated to the whole country's technology. Collected data were complemented by emissions data from the US Life Cycle Inventory of Slag Cement Manufacturing Process (available in Marceau and VanGeem, 2003)
processDocumentation.samplingDescription:
Collection of primary data from one Brazilian steelmaking plant.
The amount of the exchanges was calculated considering the average of the sample. No conversion to the geometric mean of the lognormal distribution was done, for consistency reasons with other ecoinvent datasets.

exchanges.description: Measured value. Value provided by steelmaking company. Actually, 2,238 kg of water are used for the granaulation process, but 78,62% of that water is recirculated within the company. The consumption documented here refers to the 21,38% that is lost in evaporation - to mantain water balance.

exchanges.description: Measured value. According to data provided by the steelmaking company, 21,38% of used water is evaporated.

Literature value. Emission of particulates for the granulation process stated in Marceau and VanGeem 2003. PM (dust) is generated during the "breaking" of slag through contact with pressurized cold water.
The steelmaking company states there is no mass loss during their granulation process.
